results.title: Full moon in Paris = Les Nuits de la pleine lune
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Acteurs Auteurs Associes, Les Films Ariane and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Comedies et proverbes”.
He who has two women loses his soul is the cryptic message at the start of this film in Eric Rohmer’s “Comedies et proverbes” cycle. The he of the message is, in this instance, a she - Louise who cannot bear being “loved too much”. And so she plays a game of seduction with her two aspiring lovers, one of whom she loves too, in her own way. And what if they get tired of waiting, of being available? Pascale Ogier won the best actress award at Venice in 1984 for her role as Louise. She is supported by Tcheky Karyo and Fabrice Luchini.
results.title_for_label: Full moon in Paris = Les Nuits de la pleine lune

results.title: Sightseeing
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at sightseeing in China. Tourist spots like the 13 Tombs are visited. The video is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. It also includes an interview with a Chinese tourist guide, a look at Chinese script (the city wall) and short dramas in Chinese. Interview questions are repeated and shown in Chinese script, Pin Yin and English.

results.title: School
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This video looks at school and school life in China. It is part of a television series on Chinese language and culture with an emphasis on communication. The video includes an interview with Chinese school students, a look at Chinese script (to study), the erhu (a Chinese stringed instrument), and short dramas in Chinese. The interview questions are repeated in Chinese script, Pin Yin and English.

results.title: Going out
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
Episode three covers simple vocabulary associated with excursions to the cinema, a clothes market and the zoo. Vocabulary for clothes and telling the time are included in the two dramatised situations “Sold out” and “Are there any sharks?” The calligraphy section shows the characters for film, television, eye, mirror, glasses, sun and sunglasses. Introduced by Colin McKerras. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Leisure
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
In this second episode we are introduced to simple vocabulary associated with leisure activities and the phrases “Do you like?”, “What do you like?”, “How many times?” as well as vocabulary associated with weather and family members. The calligraphy section shows words which include “ball”, eg. “football”, “volleyball”, etc. The program concludes with two short dramatised situations “The TV addict” and “The Picnic” in which a Chinese couple are introduced to the joys of the Australian barbecue. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Family and pets
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
This first episode introduces the phrases “What is your name?”, “How old are you?” and their answers, “This is”, “He is” and “She is” and words for family members and pets. At the same time we are shown the homes of two different families in Beijing, glimpses of children at school, a zoo visit and the pets the Chinese keep. We also have a brief introduction to calligraphy and how the modern pictograms have developed. Introduced by Colin McKerras. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Freedom rides
results.creator_credit: Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers”.
Charles Perkins grew up in Alice Springs in a time when racial segregation was the rule. Sent away to Adelaide for an education he became increasingly aware of the injustices perpetrated against Australian First Nations peoples. In 1965 he instigated the “Freedom ride” - a busload of concerned people, mostly students - who visited outback Australia, notably Walgett and Moree, to escalate the level of public awareness of racial intolerance in Australia. This video documents that journey and talks to those who took part.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures

results.title: Jardiwarnpa: a Warlpiri fire ceremony
results.creator_credit: Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins, City Pictures, Warlpiri Media and Warlukurlangu Artists
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
In order to combat the influence of western culture the elders of the Warlpiri people, led by Darby Jampijinpa Ross, a noted Aboriginal artist, decided to perform a fire ceremony which tells the story of Yarripiri’s journey. Yarripiri is both a real person and an incarnation of a dreamtime spirit. This video documents the preparations for the ceremony, the ceremony itself, the story the ceremony recreates and the problems the people have in performing it. Narrated by Kev Carmody.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins, City Pictures, Warlpiri Media and Warlukurlangu Artists

results.title: From little things big things grow: Kev Carmody, singer
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
Interspersed with video clips from his protest album “Pillars of society” Kev Carmody talks about his life and music. Born in Goronba, Queensland, on a cattle station, the son of an Irish stockman and his Aboriginal wife, Carmody spent his early years living off the land, but absorbing western culture through the ABC and old records. Taken away from his parents at the age of ten, he was put in a Christian school and sent home twice a year. After several years working at various menial jobs, whilst developing his music he eventually gained a Ph.D in Australian history, using oral material and methods rather than a written thesis. A fascinating portrait of a committed man.
